importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Aryeh Zalmanovich is believed to have been killed in captivity on this date, marking the likely time of death for the identified hostage.
The US-proposed ceasefire deal was signed on this date, setting the timeline for Hamas to return hostages, including the deceased, within 72 hours.
The release of the two deceased hostages occurred on this date, as part of the ceasefire implementation phase.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Under the ceasefire agreement, Hamas was required to return all deceased hostages within the first 72 hours of the deal taking effect.

keyTakeAways: Israel has identified one of two deceased hostages returned by Hamas as Aryeh Zalmanovich, aged 85, who was abducted alive and likely killed on November 17, 2023.
The other deceased hostage's identity has not been released, though their family has been notified.
The two coffins were transported into Israel and delivered to the National Institute for Forensic Medicine for identification and autopsy.
This is the 14th and 15th deceased hostage to be returned since the ceasefire agreement on October 9, 2025, with 28 total hostages expected to be returned.
Hamas has claimed significant effort and special equipment are required to recover bodies in Gaza; one previously returned body was misidentified, not intentionally sent.
Israeli intelligence assesses that Hamas may not be able to locate and return all remaining deceased hostages due to destroyed infrastructure.
US Vice President JD Vance visited Israel and emphasized the importance of returning the bodies to families, noting it is difficult and not going to happen overnight.
Vance acknowledged some bodies are buried under rubble and some are unlocated, but affirmed that recovery efforts are essential.
The ceasefire remains fragile, with both Hamas and Israel accusing each other of violations, including attacks on soldiers and breaches of agreement.

namedEntities.name: Aryeh Zalmanovich
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A deceased Israeli hostage identified by Israeli authorities
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is one of the two confirmed deceased hostages returned by Hamas, and his identification marks a key development in the transparency of the hostage recovery process.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A militant group accused by Israel of holding Israeli hostages and violating the ceasefire agreement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is required under the ceasefire deal to return all deceased hostages, including those recovered from Gaza, and has faced scrutiny for misidentifying or failing to locate bodies.

namedEntities.name: Israel Defense Forces (IDF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The military forces of Israel responsible for hostage recovery and enforcement of the ceasefire
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The IDF led the forensic identification of the remains and stated that Hamas must uphold the ceasefire terms, including returning all deceased hostages.

namedEntities.name: National Institute for Forensic Medicine
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli institution responsible for forensic examination and autopsy of the returned bodies
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It conducted the official identification and investigation of the deceased hostages' causes of death, ensuring proper medical and legal procedures.

namedEntities.name: United States (Trump administration)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The US government, including Vice President JD Vance, involved in mediating the ceasefire agreement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The US proposed the ceasefire deal and continues to support efforts to recover hostages, emphasizing family closure and humanitarian concerns.

namedEntities.name: JD Vance
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: US Vice President who visited Israel and commented on the hostage recovery process
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He publicly addressed the challenges of recovering bodies and affirmed the importance of returning deceased hostages to their families.

namedEntities.name: Ceasefire deal (Trump administration)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An agreement between Israel and Hamas to end hostilities and return hostages
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The deal mandated that Hamas return all living and deceased hostages within 72 hours, and this development reflects its ongoing implementation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Israel has identified Aryeh Zalmanovich, an 85-year-old Israeli man abducted and killed in captivity on November 17, 2023, as one of two deceased hostages returned by Hamas on October 21, 2025. The other hostage's identity remains undisclosed, though their family has been notified. The return of these bodies, the 14th and 15th since the ceasefire deal on October 9, 2025, underscores ongoing challenges in recovering all missing hostages due to rubble, destruction, and potential misidentification by Hamas. Israeli authorities emphasize the need for sensitivity and official confirmation before informing families. US Vice President JD Vance affirmed the importance of recovering bodies, noting that some are buried under rubble and recovery is difficult but not impossible. The ceasefire remains fragile, with both sides accusing each other of violations, and Israeli intelligence believes Hamas may not be able to locate all remaining deceased hostages.
tags: US involvement in Middle East conflict
title: Israel Identifies One of Two Deceased Hostages Returned by Hamas as Aryeh Zalmanovich
